title: Understanding Society: The UK Longitudinal Household Study
abstractText:
The United Kingdom Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) is a major new panel study which will provide valuable new evidence about the people of the UK, their lives, experiences, behaviours and beliefs, and will enable an unprecedented understanding of diversity within the population.  It will be the largest study of its type in the world.  It will assist with understanding the long term effects of social and economic change, as well as policy interventions designed to impact upon the general well-being of the UK population.
UKHLS is based at, and will be led by the Institute for Social and Economic Research (ISER) at the University of Essex, together with colleagues from the University of Warwick and the Institute of Education.
Key features include a total target sample size of 40,000 households including an ethnic minority sample of over 4,000 households. It will  incorporate the British Household Panel Survey.  It will involve interviews from all household members, aged 10 and above on a topic coverage relevant to a wide range of disciplines and policy fields.  It will support the collection of  health indicators and biomarkers, as well as qualitative data.  It will also be a platform for research in survey methods.
